alternative_title: Licence to be an aircraft maintenance engineer
licence_overview:
To operate as an aircraft maintenance engineer, you may need a licence from the [Civil Aviation Authority (CAA).](http://www.caa.co.uk/ "Civil Aviation Authority"{:rel="external"} 

Two licence types are appropriate – European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) Part 66 and UK National British Civil Airworthiness Requirements (BCAR) Section L.

^The EASA Part 66 licence and the BCAR Section L licence contain similar privileges, but are separated by the types of aircraft an engineer can work on – EASA aircraft and UK National Annex 2.^

This licence is separate to an aircraft maintenance licence required under Part 66 of EU Commission Regulation 2042/2003.

By holding a licence you'll be able to issue:

* maintenance review certificates for aircraft specified in your licence
* certificates of release regarding repairs, replacements, modifications, maintenance, overhauls and inspections of aircraft and equipment
* certificates for fitness for flight

##Conditions

Licences may be subject to conditions and you'll only be granted a licence if the CAA feel that you're a fit and proper person to hold a licence and that you have the relevant experience, knowledge, skill and competence in aeronautical engineering. To prove this you must supply evidence of qualifications and take any required exams or tests.

Licences will be valid for a maximum of five years and can be renewed. The CAA will maintain oversight of the licensed person to ensure that you're still a fit and proper person to hold the licence and are adequately qualified.

##Fines and penalties

You must not carry out work under your licence if you are unfit. If you do, you may be commiting an offence and be fined up to £2,500.

*[CAA]: Civil Aviation Authority 
*[EASA]: European Aviation Safety Agency 
*[BCAR]: British Civil Airworthiness Requirements
licence_short_description: Apply to the Civil Aviation Authority for an aircraft maintenance engineering licence, either an EASA Part 66 or a BCAR Section L.
overview: Get an aircraft maintenance engineer licence from the CAA, an EASA Part 66 or a BCAR Section L depending on the type of aircraft you work on
